href="#cite_note-Lionel_Messi:_The_Best_Goalscorer_Ever_but_Is_the_Barcelona_Player_the_Greatest-Ever_Footballer?-125">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup> He began the campaign by helping Barcelona win both the <a href="/wiki/2011_Supercopa_de_Espa%C3%B1a" title="2011 Supercopa de España">Spanish</a> and <a href="/wiki/2011_UEFA_Super_Cup" title="2011 UEFA Super Cup">European Super Cups</a>; in the Supercopa de España, he scored three times to achieve a 5–4 aggregate victory over Real Madrid, overtaking <a href="/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_(footballer)" title="Raúl (footballer)">Raúl</a> as the competition's all-time top scorer with eight goals.<sup id="cite_ref-Tempers_Flare_into_Brawl_as_Barcelona_Beats_Real_Madrid_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tempers_Flare_into_Brawl_as_Barcelona_Beats_Real_Madrid-126">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup> At the close of the year, on 18 December, he scored twice in the <a href="/wiki/2011_FIFA_Club_World_Cup" title="2011 FIFA Club World Cup">FIFA Club World Cup</a> <a href="/wiki/2011_FIFA_Club_World_Cup_Final" title="2011 FIFA Club World Cup Final">final</a>, a 4–0 victory over <a href="/wiki/Santos_FC" title="Santos FC">Santos</a>, earning the <a href="/wiki/List_of_FIFA_Club_World_Cup_awards#Golden_Ball" class="mw-redirect" title="List of FIFA Club World Cup awards">Golden Ball</a> as the best player of the tournament, as he had done two years previously.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup> For his efforts in 2011, he again received the <a href="/wiki/2011_FIFA_Ballon_d%27Or#Winners_and_nominees" title="2011 FIFA Ballon d&#39;Or">FIFA Ballon d'Or</a>, becoming only the fourth player in history to win the Ballon d'Or three times, after <a href="/wiki/Johan_Cruyff" title="Johan Cruyff">Johan Cruyff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michel_Platini" title="Michel Platini">Michel Platini</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Marco_van_Basten" title="Marco van Basten">Marco van Basten</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup> Additionally, he won the inaugural <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Best_Player_in_Europe_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="UEFA Best Player in Europe Award">UEFA Best Player in Europe Award</a>, a revival of the old-style Ballon d'Or.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup> By then, Messi was already widely considered one of the best footballers in history, alongside players like Diego Maradona and <a href="/wiki/Pel%C3%A9" title="Pelé">Pelé</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Boy_Genius_29-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boy_Genius-29">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="2012:_A_record-breaking_year">2012: A record-breaking year</span></h4>
<div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:33%; ;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1012376600"/>
<div class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">"I feel sorry for those who want to compete for Messi's throne – it's impossible, this kid is unique."</div>
<p><cite class="left-aligned" style="">– <a href="/wiki/Pep_Guardiola" title="Pep Guardiola">Pep Guardiola</a> after Messi became Barcelona's all-time top scorer at age 24 in March 2012<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">&#91;127&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lionel_Messi_as_Dominant_as_Michael_Jordan,_Claims_Barcelona&#39;s_Pep_Guardiola,_After_He_Breaks_Goal_Record_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lionel_Messi_as_Dominant_as_Michael_Jordan,_Claims_Barcelona&#39;s_Pep_Guardiola,_After_He_Breaks_Goal_Record-132">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup></cite>
</p>
</div>
<p>As Messi maintained his goalscoring form into the second half of the season, the year 2012 saw him break several longstanding records. On 7 March, two weeks after scoring four goals in a league fixture against <a href="/wiki/Valencia_CF" title="Valencia CF">Valencia</a>, he scored <a href="/wiki/European_Cup_and_UEFA_Champions_League_records_and_statistics#Five_goals_in_a_match" title="European Cup and UEFA Champions League records and statistics">five times</a> in a <a href="/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_UEFA_Champions_League" title="2011–12 UEFA Champions League">Champions League</a> <a href="/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_UEFA_Champions_League_knockout_phase#Round_of_16" title="2011–12 UEFA Champions League knockout phase">last 16-round</a> match against <a href="/wiki/Bayer_04_Leverkusen" title="Bayer 04 Leverkusen">Bayer Leverkusen</a>, an unprecedented achievement in the history of the competition.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup> In addition to being the joint top assist provider with five assists, this feat made him top scorer with 14 goals, tying <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Altafini" title="José Altafini">José Altafini</a>'s record from the <a href="/wiki/1962%E2%80%9363_European_Cup" title="1962–63 European Cup">1962–63 season</a>, as well as becoming only the second player after <a href="/wiki/Gerd_M%C3%BCller" title="Gerd Müller">Gerd Müller</a> to be top scorer in four campaigns.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">&#91;131&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">&#91;132&#93;</a></sup> Two weeks later, on 20 March, Messi became the top goalscorer in Barcelona's history at 24 years old, overtaking the 57-year record of <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Rodr%C3%ADguez_(footballer,_born_1920)" title="César Rodríguez (footballer, born 1920)">César Rodríguez</a>'s 232 goals with a hat-trick against <a href="/wiki/Granada_CF" title="Granada CF">Granada</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Lionel_Messi_as_Dominant_as_Michael_Jordan,_Claims_Barcelona&#39;s_Pep_Guardiola,_After_He_Breaks_Goal_Record_132-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lionel_Messi_as_Dominant_as_Michael_Jordan,_Claims_Barcelona&#39;s_Pep_Guardiola,_After_He_Breaks_Goal_Record-132">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:FC_Barcelona_-_Bayer_04_Leverkusen,_7_mar_2012_(07).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/FC_Barcelona_-_Bayer_04_Leverkusen%2C_7_mar_2012_%2807%29.jpg/220px-FC_Barcelona_-_Bayer_04_Leverkusen%2C_7_mar_2012_%2807%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/FC_Barcelona_-_Bayer_04_Leverkusen%2C_7_mar_2012_%2807%29.jpg/330px-FC_Barcelona_-_Bayer_04_Leverkusen%2C_7_mar_2012_%2807%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/FC_Barcelona_-_Bayer_04_Leverkusen%2C_7_mar_2012_%2807%29.jpg/440px-FC_Barcelona_-_Bayer_04_Leverkusen%2C_7_mar_2012_%2807%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1350" data-file-height="1013" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:FC_Barcelona_-_Bayer_04_Leverkusen,_7_mar_2012_(07).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Messi pointing to the sky following his record five-goal display against <a href="/wiki/Bayer_04_Leverkusen" title="Bayer 04 Leverkusen">Bayer Leverkusen</a> in the last 16 of the UEFA Champions League in March 2012</div></div></div>
<p>Despite Messi's individual form, Barcelona's four-year cycle of success under Guardiola – one of the greatest eras in the club's history – drew to an end.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup> Although Barcelona won the <a href="/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_Copa_del_Rey" title="2011–12 Copa del Rey">Copa del Rey</a> against Athletic Bilbao on 25 May, its 14th title of that period, the team <a href="/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_La_Liga" title="2011–12 La Liga">lost the league</a> to Real Madrid and was eliminated in the <a href="/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_UEFA_Champions_League_knockout_phase#Semi-finals" title="2011–12 UEFA Champions League knockout phase">Champions League semi-finals</a> by the eventual <a href="/wiki/2012_UEFA_Champions_League_Final" title="2012 UEFA Champions League Final">champions</a>, Chelsea, with Messi sending a crucial second-leg penalty kick against the crossbar.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">&#91;134&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup> In Barça's last home league match on 5 May, against Espanyol, Messi scored all four goals before approaching the bench to embrace Guardiola, who had announced his resignation as manager.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">&#91;136&#93;</a></sup> He finished <a href="/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_FC_Barcelona_season" title="2011–12 FC Barcelona season">the season</a> as league top scorer in Spain and Europe for a second time, with 50 goals, a La Liga record, while his <a href="/wiki/European_association_football_club_records#Most_goals_in_a_season" class="mw-redirect" title="European association football club records">73 goals in all competitions</a> surpassed <a href="/wiki/Gerd_M%C3%BCller" title="Gerd Müller">Gerd Müller</a>'s 67 goals in the <a href="/wiki/1972%E2%80%9373_Bundesliga" title="1972–73 Bundesliga">1972–73 Bundesliga</a> season, making him the single-season top scorer in the history of European club football.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">&#91;137&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">&#91;138&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Under manager <a href="/wiki/Tito_Vilanova" title="Tito Vilanova">Tito Vilanova</a>, who had first coached him aged 14 at <i>La Masia</i>, Messi helped the club achieve its best-ever start to a <a href="/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_La_Liga" title="2012–13 La Liga">La Liga season</a> during the second half of 2012, amassing 55 points by the competition's midway point, a record in Spanish football.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">&#91;139&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup> A double scored on 9 December against <a href="/wiki/Real_Betis" title="Real Betis">Real Betis</a> saw Messi break two longstanding records: he surpassed César Rodríguez's record of 190 league goals, becoming Barcelona's all-time top scorer in La Liga, and Gerd Müller's record of most goals scored in a calendar year, overtaking his 85 goals scored in 1972 for Bayern Munich and <a href="/wiki/Germany_national_football_team" title="Germany national football team">West Germany</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">&#91;141&#93;</a></sup> Messi sent Müller a number 10 Barcelona shirt, signed "with respect and admiration", after breaking his 40-year record.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup> At the close of the year, Messi had scored a record 91 goals in all competitions for Barcelona and Argentina.<sup id="cite_ref-Barcelona&#39;s_Lionel_Messi_Becomes_Most_Decorated_Player_in_History_after_Winning_Unprecedented_Fourth_Straight_Ballon_d&#39;Or_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barcelona&#39;s_Lionel_Messi_Becomes_Most_Decorated_Player_in_History_after_Winning_Unprecedented_Fourth_Straight_Ballon_d&#39;Or-147">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup> Although <a href="/wiki/FIFA" title="FIFA">FIFA</a> did not acknowledge the achievement, citing verifiability issues, he received the <i><a href="/wiki/Guinness_World_Records" title="Guinness World Records">Guinness World Records</a></i> title for most goals scored in a calendar year.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Barcelona_Star_Lionel_Messi_Sets_New_Goal-Scoring_Record_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barcelona_Star_Lionel_Messi_Sets_New_Goal-Scoring_Record-149">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup> As the odds-on favourite, Messi again won the <a href="/wiki/2012_FIFA_Ballon_d%27Or#Winners_and_nominees" title="2012 FIFA Ballon d&#39;Or">FIFA Ballon d'Or</a>, becoming the only player in history to win the Ballon d'Or four times.<sup id="cite_ref-Barcelona&#39;s_Lionel_Messi_Becomes_Most_Decorated_Player_in_History_after_Winning_Unprecedented_Fourth_Straight_Ballon_d&#39;Or_147-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barcelona&#39;s_Lionel_Messi_Becomes_Most_Decorated_Player_in_History_after_Winning_Unprecedented_Fourth_Straight_Ballon_d&#39;Or-147">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="2013.E2.80.9314:_Messidependencia"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2013–14:_Messidependencia">2013–14: <i>Messidependencia</i></span></h4>
<p>Barcelona had virtually secured their La Liga title by the start of 2013, eventually equalling Real Madrid's 100-point record of the previous season. However, their performances deteriorated in the second half of the <a href="/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_FC_Barcelona_season" title="2012–13 FC Barcelona season">2012–13 campaign</a>, concurrently with Vilanova's absence due to ill health.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup> After losing successive <i>Clásicos</i>, including the <a href="/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_Copa_del_Rey" title="2012–13 Copa del Rey">Copa del Rey</a> <a href="/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_Copa_del_Rey#Semi-finals" title="2012–13 Copa del Rey">semi-finals</a>, they were nearly eliminated in the <a href="/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_UEFA_Champions_League_knockout_phase#Round_of_16" title="2012–13 UEFA Champions League knockout phase">first knockout round</a> of the <a href="/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_UEFA_Champions_League" title="2012–13 UEFA Champions League">Champions League</a> by <a href="/wiki/A.C._Milan" title="A.C. Milan">Milan</a>, but a revival of form in the second leg led to a 4–0 comeback, with two goals and an assist from Messi.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup> Now in his ninth senior season with Barcelona, Messi signed a new contract on 7 February, committing himself to the club through 2018, while his fixed wage rose to €13&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBalagué2013556_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBalagué2013556-153">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup> He wore the captain's armband for the first time a month later, on 17 March, in a league match against <a href="/wiki/Rayo_Vallecano" title="Rayo Vallecano">Rayo Vallecano</a>; by then, he had become the team's tactical focal point to a degree that was arguably rivalled only by former Barcelona players <a href="/wiki/Josep_Samitier" title="Josep Samitier">Josep Samitier</a>, <a href="/wiki/L%C3%A1szl%C3%B3_Kubala" title="László Kubala">László Kubala</a> and Johan Cruyff.<sup id="cite_ref-Captain_Messi_Inspires_Another_Barça_League_Triumph_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Captain_Messi_Inspires_Another_Barça_League_Triumph-155">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup> Since his evolution into a false nine three years earlier, his input into the team's attack had increased; from 24% in their treble-winning campaign, his goal contribution rose to more than 40% that season.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECaioli2015ch._38_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECaioli2015ch._38-156">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="quotebox pullquote floatleft" style="width:29%; ;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1012376600"/>
<div class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">"In Leo we are talking about the best player in the world and when things are not going well you have to use him. Even if he is half lame, his presence on the pitch is enough to lift us and our play in general."</div>
<p><cite class="left-aligned" style="">– Defender <a href="/wiki/Gerard_Piqu%C3%A9" title="Gerard Piqué">Gerard Piqué</a> explains Barcelona's reliance on an unfit Messi against <a href="/wiki/Paris_Saint-Germain_F.C." title="Paris Saint-Germain F.C.">Paris Saint-Germain</a> in April 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup></cite>
</p>
</div>
<p>After four largely injury-free seasons, the muscular injuries that had previously plagued Messi reoccurred. After he suffered a hamstring strain on 2 April, during the first <a href="/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_UEFA_Champions_League_knockout_phase#Quarter-finals" title="2012–13 UEFA Champions League knockout phase">quarter-final</a> against <a href="/wiki/Paris_Saint-Germain_F.C." title="Paris Saint-Germain F.C.">Paris Saint-Germain</a>, his appearances became sporadic. In the second leg against PSG, with an underperforming Barcelona down a goal, Messi came off the bench in the second half and within nine minutes helped create their game-tying goal, which allowed them to progress to the semi-finals. Still unfit, he proved ineffective during the first leg against Bayern Munich and was unable to play at all during the second, as Barcelona were <a href="/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_UEFA_Champions_League_knockout_phase#Semi-finals" title="2012–13 UEFA Champions League knockout phase">defeated 7–0 on aggregate</a> by the eventual champions.<sup id="cite_ref-Messidependencia_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Messidependencia-158">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup> These matches gave credence to the notion of <i>Messidependencia</i>, Barcelona's perceived tactical and psychological dependence on their star player.<sup id="cite_ref-Messidependencia_158-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Messidependencia-158">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Leo_Messi_v_Almeria_020314_(extra_crop).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Leo_Messi_v_Almeria_020314_%28extra_crop%29.jpg/190px-Leo_Messi_v_Almeria_020314_%28extra_crop%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="253" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Leo_Messi_v_Almeria_020314_%28extra_crop%29.jpg/285px-Leo_Messi_v_Almeria_020314_%28extra_crop%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Leo_Messi_v_Almeria_020314_%28extra_crop%29.jpg/380px-Leo_Messi_v_Almeria_020314_%28extra_crop%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="520" data-file-height="693" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Leo_Messi_v_Almeria_020314_(extra_crop).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Messi during a game against <a href="/wiki/UD_Almer%C3%ADa" title="UD Almería">Almería</a> in March 2014</div></div></div>
<p>Messi continued to struggle with injury throughout 2013, eventually parting ways with his long-time personal physiotherapist.<sup id="cite_ref-Rumours_of_Lionel_Messi_Rift_with_Barcelona_Rubbished_Be_Representatives_of_the_Argentina_International_159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rumours_of_Lionel_Messi_Rift_with_Barcelona_Rubbished_Be_Representatives_of_the_Argentina_International-159">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup> Further damage to his hamstring sustained on 12 May ended his goalscoring streak of 21 consecutive league games, a worldwide record; he had netted 33 goals during his run, including a four-goal display against <a href="/wiki/CA_Osasuna" title="CA Osasuna">Osasuna</a>, while becoming the first player to score consecutively against all 19 opposition teams in La Liga.<sup id="cite_ref-Messi_Worry_Mars_Barca&#39;s_Title_Joy_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Messi_Worry_Mars_Barca&#39;s_Title_Joy-160">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Messi_&#39;Breaks_Record&#39;_by_Scoring_in_17th_Consecutive_La_Liga_Game_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Messi_&#39;Breaks_Record&#39;_by_Scoring_in_17th_Consecutive_La_Liga_Game-161">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup> With 60 goals  in all competitions, including 46 goals in La Liga, he finished the campaign as league top scorer in Spain and Europe for the second consecutive year, becoming the first player in history to win the <a href="/wiki/European_Golden_Shoe" title="European Golden Shoe">European Golden Shoe</a> three times.<sup id="cite_ref-Lionel_Messi_Awarded_Golden_Shoe_for_Third_Time_after_46_La_Liga_Goals_for_Barcelona_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lionel_Messi_Awarded_Golden_Shoe_for_Third_Time_after_46_La_Liga_Goals_for_Barcelona-162">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Matches_2012–13_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Matches_2012–13-163">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup> Following an irregular start to the <a href="/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_FC_Barcelona_season" title="2013–14 FC Barcelona season">new season</a> under manager <a href="/wiki/Gerardo_Martino" title="Gerardo Martino">Gerardo Martino</a>, formerly of his boyhood club Newell's Old Boys, Messi suffered his fifth injury of 2013 when he tore his hamstring on 10 November, leaving him sidelined for two months.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBalagué2013587–592_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBalagué2013587–592-164">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup> Despite his injuries, he was voted runner-up for the <a href="/wiki/2013_FIFA_Ballon_d%27Or" title="2013 FIFA Ballon d&#39;Or">FIFA Ballon d'Or</a>, relinquishing the award after a four-year monopoly to Cristiano Ronaldo.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During the second half of the 2013–14 season, doubts persisted over Messi's form, leading to a perception among the <i>culés</i> that he was reserving himself for the <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2014 FIFA World Cup">2014 FIFA World Cup</a>. Statistically, his contribution of goals, shots, and passes had dropped significantly compared to previous seasons.<sup id="cite_ref-Real_Madrid_v_Barcelona:_Has_Ronaldo_Overtaken_Messi?_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Real_Madrid_v_Barcelona:_Has_Ronaldo_Overtaken_Messi?-167">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-One_Flick_of_Lionel_Messi&#39;s_Left_Foot_Ends_Talk_of_Crisis_at_Barcelona_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-One_Flick_of_Lionel_Messi&#39;s_Left_Foot_Ends_Talk_of_Crisis_at_Barcelona-168">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup> He still managed to break two longstanding records in a span of seven days: a hat-trick on 16 March against Osasuna saw him overtake <a href="/wiki/Paulino_Alc%C3%A1ntara" title="Paulino Alcántara">Paulino Alcántara</a>'s 369 goals to become Barcelona's top goalscorer in all competitions including friendlies, while another hat-trick against Real Madrid on 23 March made him the <a href="/wiki/El_Cl%C3%A1sico#Top_goalscorers" title="El Clásico">all-time top scorer</a> in <i>El Clásico</i>, ahead of the 18 goals scored by former Real Madrid player <a href="/wiki/Alfredo_Di_St%C3%A9fano" title="Alfredo Di Stéfano">Alfredo Di Stéfano</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Real_Madrid_v_Barcelona:_Has_Ronaldo_Overtaken_Messi?_167-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Real_Madrid_v_Barcelona:_Has_Ronaldo_Overtaken_Messi?-167">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Real_Madrid_3_Barcelona_4_Match_Report:_Lionel_Messi_Hat-Trick_Out-Guns_Cristiano_Ronaldo_in_Seven-Goal_El_Clásico_Thriller_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Real_Madrid_3_Barcelona_4_Match_Report:_Lionel_Messi_Hat-Trick_Out-Guns_Cristiano_Ronaldo_in_Seven-Goal_El_Clásico_Thriller-169">&#91;165&#93;</a></sup> Messi finished the campaign with his worst output in five seasons, though he still managed to score 41 goals in all competitions.<sup id="cite_ref-One_Flick_of_Lionel_Messi&#39;s_Left_Foot_Ends_Talk_of_Crisis_at_Barcelona_168-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-One_Flick_of_Lionel_Messi&#39;s_Left_Foot_Ends_Talk_of_Crisis_at_Barcelona-168">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Matches_2013–14_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Matches_2013–14-170">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup> For the first time in five years, Barcelona ended the season without a major trophy; they were defeated in the <a href="/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_Copa_del_Rey" title="2013–14 Copa del Rey">Copa del Rey</a> <a href="/wiki/2014_Copa_del_Rey_Final" title="2014 Copa del Rey Final">final</a> by Real Madrid and <a href="/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_La_Liga" title="2013–14 La Liga">lost the league</a> in the last game to Atlético Madrid, causing Messi to be booed by sections of fans at the Camp Nou.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup> After prolonged speculation over his future with the club, Messi signed a new contract on 19 May 2014, only a year after his last contractual update; his salary increased to €20&#160;million, or €36&#160;million before taxes, the highest wage in the sport.<sup id="cite_ref-Messi,_the_(Very)_Good_Payroll_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Messi,_the_(Very)_Good_Payroll-172">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="2014.E2.80.9315:_An_historic_treble"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2014–15:_An_historic_treble">2014–15: An historic treble</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Leo_Messi_v_Granada_2014.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Leo_Messi_v_Granada_2014.jpg/220px-Leo_Messi_v_Granada_2014.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Leo_Messi_v_Granada_2014.jpg/330px-Leo_Messi_v_Granada_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Leo_Messi_v_Granada_2014.jpg/440px-Leo_Messi_v_Granada_2014.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1450" data-file-height="1088" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Leo_Messi_v_Granada_2014.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Messi celebrating his second goal against <a href="/wiki/Granada_CF" title="Granada CF">Granada</a> in September 2014</div></div></div>
<p>Under new manager and former captain <a href="/wiki/Luis_Enrique" title="Luis Enrique">Luis Enrique</a>, Messi experienced a largely injury-free start to the <a href="/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_FC_Barcelona_season" title="2014–15 FC Barcelona season">2014–15 season</a>, allowing him to break three more longstanding records towards the end of the year.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup> A hat-trick scored against Sevilla on 22 November made him the <a href="/wiki/La_Liga#Most_goals" title="La Liga">all-time top scorer in La Liga</a>, as he surpassed the 59-year record of 251 league goals held by <a href="/wiki/Telmo_Zarra" title="Telmo Zarra">Telmo Zarra</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">&#91;170&#93;</a></sup> A third hat-trick, scored against city rivals Espanyol on 7 December, allowed him to surpass César Rodríguez as the all-time top scorer in the <i><a href="/wiki/Derbi_barcelon%C3%AD" title="Derbi barceloní">Derbi barceloní</a></i> with 12 goals.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Derby_Is_a_Monologue_of_Messi_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Derby_Is_a_Monologue_of_Messi-175">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup> Messi again placed second in the <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_Ballon_d%27Or#Winners" title="2014 FIFA Ballon d&#39;Or">FIFA Ballon d'Or</a> behind Cristiano Ronaldo, largely owing to his second-place achievement with Argentina at the World Cup.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>At the start of 2015, Barcelona were perceived to be headed for another disappointing end to the season, with renewed speculation in the media that Messi was leaving the club. A turning point came on 11 January during a 3–1 victory over Atlético Madrid, the first time Barça's attacking trident of Messi, <a href="/wiki/Luis_Su%C3%A1rez" title="Luis Suárez">Luis Suárez</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neymar" title="Neymar">Neymar</a>, dubbed "MSN", each scored in a match, marking the beginning of a highly successful run.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Barcelona_Transform_Their_Season_from_Trouble_to_a_Possible_Treble_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barcelona_Transform_Their_Season_from_Trouble_to_a_Possible_Treble-178">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup> After five years of playing in the centre of the pitch, Messi had returned to his old position on the right wing late the previous year, by his own suggestion according to Suárez, their striker.<sup id="cite_ref-Barcelona_Transform_Their_Season_from_Trouble_to_a_Possible_Treble_178-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barcelona_Transform_Their_Season_from_Trouble_to_a_Possible_Treble-178">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Motivated_Lionel_Messi_Transforms_Barcelona&#39;s_Hopes_for_Trophy_Treble_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Motivated_Lionel_Messi_Transforms_Barcelona&#39;s_Hopes_for_Trophy_Treble-179">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup> From there, he regained his best – arguably his best-ever – form, while Suárez and Neymar ended the team's attacking dependency on their star player.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">&#91;177&#93;</a></sup> With 58 goals  from Messi, the trio scored a total of 122 goals in all competitions that season, a record in Spanish football.<sup id="cite_ref-Barcelona&#39;s_Luis_Suárez,_Leo_Messi_and_Neymar_Too_Good_for_Juventus_182-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barcelona&#39;s_Luis_Suárez,_Leo_Messi_and_Neymar_Too_Good_for_Juventus-182">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Moment_of_the_Champions_League_final_FC_Barcelona_-_Juventus_2015.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Moment_of_the_Champions_League_final_FC_Barcelona_-_Juventus_2015.jpg/220px-Moment_of_the_Champions_League_final_FC_Barcelona_-_Juventus_2015.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="162" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Moment_of_the_Champions_League_final_FC_Barcelona_-_Juventus_2015.jpg/330px-Moment_of_the_Champions_League_final_FC_Barcelona_-_Juventus_2015.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Moment_of_the_Champions_League_final_FC_Barcelona_-_Juventus_2015.jpg/440px-Moment_of_the_Champions_League_final_FC_Barcelona_-_Juventus_2015.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2676" data-file-height="1970" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Moment_of_the_Champions_League_final_FC_Barcelona_-_Juventus_2015.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Messi dribbling past <a href="/wiki/Juventus_F.C." title="Juventus F.C.">Juventus</a> defender <a href="/wiki/Patrice_Evra" title="Patrice Evra">Patrice Evra</a> during the <a href="/wiki/2015_UEFA_Champions_League_Final" title="2015 UEFA Champions League Final">UEFA Champions League Final</a> in June 2015. Prior to the match, Juventus captain <a href="/wiki/Gianluigi_Buffon" title="Gianluigi Buffon">Gianluigi Buffon</a> stated, "Messi is an alien that dedicates himself to playing with humans".<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Towards the end of the campaign, Messi scored in a 1–0 away win over Atlético Madrid on 17 May, securing the <a href="/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_La_Liga" title="2014–15 La Liga">La Liga title</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup> Among his 43 league goals that season was a hat-trick scored in 11 minutes against Rayo Vallecano on 8 March, the fastest of his senior career; it was his 32nd hat-trick overall for Barcelona, allowing him to overtake Telmo Zarra with the most hat-tricks in Spanish football.<sup id="cite_ref-Supporters,_Superstars_and_Goals_Galore_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Supporters,_Superstars_and_Goals_Galore-185">&#91;181&#93;</a></sup> As the season's top assist provider with 18 he surpassed <a href="/wiki/Lu%C3%ADs_Figo" title="Luís Figo">Luís Figo</a> with the most assists in La Liga;<sup id="cite_ref-Assist_statistics_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Assist_statistics-186">&#91;note 3&#93;</a></sup> he made his record 106th assist in a fixture against <a href="/wiki/Levante_UD" title="Levante UD">Levante</a> on 15 February, in which he also scored a hat-trick.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Messi_Is_Also_a_Legend_in_the_Historical_Assist_Ranking_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Messi_Is_Also_a_Legend_in_the_Historical_Assist_Ranking-188">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Messi_Notches_Assist_Record_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Messi_Notches_Assist_Record-189">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup> Messi scored twice as Barcelona defeated Athletic Bilbao 3–1 in the <a href="/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_Copa_del_Rey" title="2014–15 Copa del Rey">Copa del Rey</a> <a href="/wiki/2015_Copa_del_Rey_Final" title="2015 Copa del Rey Final">final</a> on 30 May, achieving the sixth double in their history. His opening goal was hailed as one of the greatest in his career; he collected the ball near the halfway line and beat four opposing players, before feinting the goalkeeper to score in a tight space by the near post.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_UEFA_Champions_League" title="2014–15 UEFA Champions League">Champions League</a>, Messi scored twice and assisted on another in their 3–0 <a href="/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_UEFA_Champions_League_knockout_phase#Semi-finals" title="2014–15 UEFA Champions League knockout phase">semi-final</a> victory over Bayern Munich, now under the stewardship of Guardiola.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup> His second goal, which came only three minutes after his first, saw him chip the ball over goalkeeper <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Neuer" title="Manuel Neuer">Manuel Neuer</a> after his dribble past <a href="/wiki/J%C3%A9r%C3%B4me_Boateng" title="Jérôme Boateng">Jérôme Boateng</a> had made the defender drop to the ground; it went <a href="/wiki/Internet_meme" title="Internet meme">viral</a>, becoming the year's most tweeted about sporting moment, and was named the best goal of the season by <a href="/wiki/UEFA" title="UEFA">UEFA</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup> Despite a second-leg loss, Barcelona progressed to the <a href="/wiki/2015_UEFA_Champions_League_Final" title="2015 UEFA Champions League Final">final</a> on 6 June in <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>, where they defeated Juventus 3–1 to win their second treble, becoming the first team in history to do so.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup> Although Messi did not score, he participated in each of his side's goals, particularly the second as he forced a parried save from goalkeeper <a href="/wiki/Gianluigi_Buffon" title="Gianluigi Buffon">Gianluigi Buffon</a> from which Suárez scored the match-winning goal on the rebound.<sup id="cite_ref-Barcelona&#39;s_Luis_Suárez,_Leo_Messi_and_Neymar_Too_Good_for_Juventus_182-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barcelona&#39;s_Luis_Suárez,_Leo_Messi_and_Neymar_Too_Good_for_Juventus-182">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup> In addition to being the top assist provider with six assists, Messi finished the competition as the joint top scorer with ten goals, which earned him the distinction of being the first player ever to achieve the top scoring mark in five Champions League seasons.<sup id="cite_ref-UEFA_Champions_League_2014–15:_Statistics_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UEFA_Champions_League_2014–15:_Statistics-196">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_Ultimate_Record-Breaking_Preview_to_the_UEFA_Champions_League_Final_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Ultimate_Record-Breaking_Preview_to_the_UEFA_Champions_League_Final-197">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup> For his efforts during the season, he received the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Best_Player_in_Europe_Award#2014–15" class="mw-redirect" title="UEFA Best Player in Europe Award">UEFA Best Player in Europe award</a> for a second time.<sup id="cite_ref-Messi_Beats_Ronaldo_for_2014–15_UEFA_Best_Player_in_Europe_Award_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Messi_Beats_Ronaldo_for_2014–15_UEFA_Best_Player_in_Europe_Award-198">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="2015.E2.80.9316:_Domestic_success"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2015–16:_Domestic_success">2015–16: Domestic success</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lionel_Messi.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Lionel_Messi.png/170px-Lionel_Messi.png" decoding="async" width="170" height="242" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Lionel_Messi.png/255px-Lionel_Messi.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Lionel_Messi.png/340px-Lionel_Messi.png 2x" data-file-width="632" data-file-height="900" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Lionel_Messi.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Messi holding off Sevilla's <a href="/wiki/%C3%89ver_Banega" title="Éver Banega">Éver Banega</a> during the <a href="/wiki/2015_UEFA_Super_Cup" title="2015 UEFA Super Cup">2015 UEFA Super Cup</a> in <a href="/wiki/Tbilisi" title="Tbilisi">Tbilisi</a></div></div></div>
<p>Messi opened the <a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_FC_Barcelona_season" title="2015–16 FC Barcelona season">2015–16 season</a> by scoring twice from <a href="/wiki/Free_kick_(association_football)" title="Free kick (association football)">free kicks</a> in Barcelona's 5–4 victory (<a href="/wiki/Overtime_(sports)" title="Overtime (sports)">after extra time</a>) over Sevilla in the <a href="/wiki/2015_UEFA_Super_Cup" title="2015 UEFA Super Cup">UEFA Super Cup</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup> On 16 September, he became the youngest player to make 100 appearances in the <a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_UEFA_Champions_League" title="2015–16 UEFA Champions League">UEFA Champions League</a> in a 1–1 away draw to <a href="/wiki/A.S._Roma" title="A.S. Roma">Roma</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Florenzi&#39;s_goal_vs._Barca_one_for_the_ages_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Florenzi&#39;s_goal_vs._Barca_one_for_the_ages-200">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup> After a knee injury, he returned to the pitch on 21 November, making a substitute appearance in Barcelona's 4–0 away win over rivals Real Madrid in <i>El Clásico</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">&#91;196&#93;</a></sup> Messi capped off the year by winning the <a href="/wiki/2015_FIFA_Club_World_Cup" title="2015 FIFA Club World Cup">2015 FIFA Club World Cup</a> <a href="/wiki/2015_FIFA_Club_World_Cup_Final" title="2015 FIFA Club World Cup Final">Final</a> on 20 December, collecting his fifth club trophy of 2015 as Barcelona defeated <a href="/wiki/Club_Atl%C3%A9tico_River_Plate" title="Club Atlético River Plate">River Plate</a> 3–0 in <a href="/wiki/Yokohama" title="Yokohama">Yokohama</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">&#91;197&#93;</a></sup> On 30 December, Messi scored on his 500th appearance for Barcelona, in a 4–0 home win over Real Betis.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 11 January 2016, Messi won the <a href="/wiki/2015_FIFA_Ballon_d%27Or" title="2015 FIFA Ballon d&#39;Or">FIFA Ballon d'Or</a> for a record fifth time in his career.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup> On 3 February, he scored a hat-trick in Barcelona's 7–0 win against Valencia in the first leg of the <a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_Copa_del_Rey" title="2015–16 Copa del Rey">Copa del Rey</a> <a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_Copa_del_Rey#Semi-finals" title="2015–16 Copa del Rey">semi-final</a> at the Camp Nou.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup> In a 6–1 home win against <a href="/wiki/RC_Celta_de_Vigo" title="RC Celta de Vigo">Celta Vigo</a> in the league, Messi assisted Suárez from a <a href="/wiki/Penalty_kick_(association_football)" title="Penalty kick (association football)">penalty kick</a>. Some saw it as "a touch of genius", while others criticised it as being disrespectful to the opponent. The Celta players never complained and their coach defended the penalty, stating, "Barca's forwards are very respectful." The penalty routine has been compared to that of <i>Barça</i> icon Johan Cruyff in 1982, who was battling lung cancer, leading many fans to indicate that the penalty was a tribute to him. Cruyff himself was "very happy" with the play, insisting "it was legal and entertaining".<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 17 February, Messi reached his 300th league goal in a 1–3 away win against <a href="/wiki/Sporting_de_Gij%C3%B3n" title="Sporting de Gijón">Sporting de Gijón</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup> A few days later, he scored both goals in Barcelona's 0–2 win against Arsenal at the <a href="/wiki/Emirates_Stadium" title="Emirates Stadium">Emirates Stadium</a>, in the first leg of the <a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_UEFA_Champions_League" title="2015–16 UEFA Champions League">2015–16 UEFA Champions League</a> <a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_UEFA_Champions_League_knockout_phase#Round_of_16" title="2015–16 UEFA Champions League knockout phase">round of 16</a>, with the second goal being Barcelona's 10,000th in official competitions.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup> On 17 April, Messi ended a five-match scoring drought with his 500th senior career goal for club and country in Barcelona's 2–1 home loss to Valencia.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup> Messi finished the 2015–16 season by setting up both goals in Barcelona's 2–0 extra time win over Sevilla in the <a href="/wiki/2016_Copa_del_Rey_Final" title="2016 Copa del Rey Final">2016 Copa del Rey Final</a>, at the <a href="/wiki/Vicente_Calder%C3%B3n_Stadium" title="Vicente Calderón Stadium">Vicente Calderón Stadium</a>, on 22 May 2016, as the club celebrated winning the domestic double for the second consecutive season.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup> In total, Messi scored 41 goals and provided 23 assists, as Barcelona's attacking trio managed a Spanish record of 131 goals throughout the season, breaking the record they had set the previous season.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="2016.E2.80.9317:_Fourth_Golden_Boot"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2016–17:_Fourth_Golden_Boot">2016–17: Fourth Golden Boot</span></h4>
<div class="quotebox pullquote floatleft" style="width:33%; ;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1012376600"/>
<div class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">"[Messi] is indispensable, but the rest of us are dispensable. – No, the club is bigger than any manager, than any player... except Leo. That's the reality, and you have to accept it."</div>
<p><cite class="left-aligned" style="">– In an interview with Barcelona's official magazine, <a href="/wiki/Javier_Mascherano" title="Javier Mascherano">Javier Mascherano</a> outlines Messi's importance to the team.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup></cite>
</p>
</div>
<p>Messi opened the <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_FC_Barcelona_season" title="2016–17 FC Barcelona season">2016–17 season</a> by lifting the <a href="/wiki/2016_Supercopa_de_Espa%C3%B1a" title="2016 Supercopa de España">2016 Supercopa de España</a> as Barcelona's captain in the absence of the injured Andrés Iniesta;<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup> he set-up <a href="/wiki/Munir_El_Haddadi" title="Munir El Haddadi">Munir</a>'s goal in a 2–0 away win over Sevilla in the first leg on 14 August,<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup> and subsequently scored and assisted in a 3–0 win in the return leg on 17 August.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup> Three days later, he scored two goals and provided an assist to lead Barcelona to a 6–2 victory against Real Betis in the opening game of the <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_La_Liga" title="2016–17 La Liga">2016–17 La Liga</a> season.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup> On 13 September 2016, Messi scored his first hat-trick of the season in the opening game of the <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_UEFA_Champions_League" title="2016–17 UEFA Champions League">2016–17 UEFA Champions League</a> campaign against <a href="/wiki/Celtic_F.C." title="Celtic F.C.">Celtic</a> in a 7–0 victory; this was also Messi's sixth hat-trick in the Champions League, the most by any player. A week later, Messi sustained a <a href="/wiki/Groin" title="Groin">groin</a> injury in a 1–1 draw against Atlético Madrid and was ruled out with injury for three weeks.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup> He marked his return with a goal, scoring three minutes after coming off the bench in a 4–0 home win over <a href="/wiki/Deportivo_de_La_Coru%C3%B1a" title="Deportivo de La Coruña">Deportivo de La Coruña</a>, on 16 October.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup> Three days after this, he netted his thirty-seventh club hat-trick as Barcelona defeated <a href="/wiki/Manchester_City_F.C." title="Manchester City F.C.">Manchester City</a> 4–0.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup> On 1 November, Messi scored his 54th Champions League group stage goal in Barcelona's 3–1 away loss to Manchester City, surpassing the previous record of 53 goals held by Raúl.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Leo_Messi_2016.PNG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Leo_Messi_2016.PNG/170px-Leo_Messi_2016.PNG" decoding="async" width="170" height="282" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Leo_Messi_2016.PNG/255px-Leo_Messi_2016.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Leo_Messi_2016.PNG/340px-Leo_Messi_2016.PNG 2x" data-file-width="469" data-file-height="779" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Leo_Messi_2016.PNG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Messi prior to a friendly game with <a href="/wiki/Al_Ahli_SC_(Doha)" title="Al Ahli SC (Doha)">Al Ahli SC</a> in <a href="/wiki/Doha" title="Doha">Doha</a>, Qatar in December 2016</div></div></div>
<p>Messi finished the year with 51 goals, making him Europe's top scorer, one ahead of Zlatan Ibrahimovi.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup> After placing second in the <a href="/wiki/2016_Ballon_d%27Or" title="2016 Ballon d&#39;Or">2016 Ballon d'Or</a>, on 9 January 2017 Messi also finished in second place – behind Cristiano Ronaldo once again – in the <a href="/wiki/The_Best_FIFA_Football_Awards_2016#The_Best_FIFA_Men&#39;s_Player" title="The Best FIFA Football Awards 2016">2016 Best FIFA Men's Player Award</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup> On 11 January, Messi scored from a free-kick in Barcelona's 3–1 victory against Athletic Bilbao in the second leg of the <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_Copa_del_Rey#Round_of_16" title="2016–17 Copa del Rey">round of 16</a> of the <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_Copa_del_Rey" title="2016–17 Copa del Rey">Copa del Rey</a>, which enabled Barcelona to advance to the <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_Copa_del_Rey#Quarter-finals" title="2016–17 Copa del Rey">quarter-finals</a> of the competition; with his 26th goal from a free-kick for Barcelona in all competitions, he equalled the club's all-time record, which had previously been set by <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Koeman" title="Ronald Koeman">Ronald Koeman</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Lionel_Messi_equals_Ronald_Koeman&#39;s_Barcelona_free-kick_record_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lionel_Messi_equals_Ronald_Koeman&#39;s_Barcelona_free-kick_record-224">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup> In his next league match, on 14 January, Messi scored in a 5–0 win against <a href="/wiki/UD_Las_Palmas" title="UD Las Palmas">Las Palmas</a>; with this goal, he equalled Raúl's record for the most teams scored against in La Liga (35).<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 4 February 2017, Messi scored his 27th free-kick for Barcelona in a 3–0 home win over Athletic Bilbao in the league, overtaking Koeman as the club's all-time top-scorer from free-kicks.<sup id="cite_ref-free_kick_record_226-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-free_kick_record-226">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup> On 23 April, Messi scored twice in a 3–2 away win over Real Madrid. His game-winning goal in stoppage time was his 500th for Barcelona.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup> His memorable <a href="/wiki/Goal_celebration" title="Goal celebration">celebration</a> saw him taking off his Barcelona shirt and holding it up to incensed Real Madrid fans – with his name and number facing the crowd.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup> On 27 May, Messi scored a goal and set up another for <a href="/wiki/Paco_Alc%C3%A1cer" title="Paco Alcácer">Paco Alcácer</a> in the <a href="/wiki/2017_Copa_del_Rey_Final" title="2017 Copa del Rey Final">2017 Copa del Rey Final</a>, helping Barcelona to a 3–1 victory over <a href="/wiki/Deportivo_Alav%C3%A9s" title="Deportivo Alavés">Alavés</a>, and was named <a href="/wiki/Player_of_the_match" title="Player of the match">Man of the Match</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup> In total, Messi finished the 2016–17 season with 54 goals and 16 assists, while his 37 goals in La Liga saw him claim both the <a href="/wiki/Pichichi_Trophy" title="Pichichi Trophy">Pichichi</a> and European Golden Boot Awards for the fourth time in his career.<sup id="cite_ref-MessiFourthGoldenShoe_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MessiFourthGoldenShoe-230">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="2017.E2.80.9318:_Domestic_double_and_a_record_fifth_Golden_Boot"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2017–18:_Domestic_double_and_a_record_fifth_Golden_Boot">2017–18: Domestic double and a record fifth Golden Boot</span></h4>
<p>Messi opened the <a href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_FC_Barcelona_season" title="2017–18 FC Barcelona season">2017–18 season</a> by converting a penalty in Barcelona's 1–3 first leg home defeat to Real Madrid in <a href="/wiki/2017_Supercopa_de_Espa%C3%B1a" title="2017 Supercopa de España">Supercopa de España</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup> Thereby, Messi also extended his <i>El Clásico</i> goalscoring record with the goal being his 24th official and 25th overall.<sup id="cite_ref-El_ClasicoLM_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-El_ClasicoLM-232">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup>
On 9 September, Messi scored his first hat-trick of the 2017–18 league campaign, against Espanyol in <i>Derbi barceloní</i>, thus helping to secure a 5–0 home victory for <i>Blaugrana</i> over local rivals.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup> Messi netted twice against Gianluigi Buffon, on 12 September, as Barça defeated the <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_Serie_A" title="2016–17 Serie A">last season's Italian champions</a> Juventus 3–0 at home in the <a href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_UEFA_Champions_League" title="2017–18 UEFA Champions League">UEFA Champions League</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup> On 19 September, Messi found the net four times in a 6–1 trashing of <a href="/wiki/SD_Eibar" title="SD Eibar">Eibar</a> at the Camp Nou in <a href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_La_Liga" title="2017–18 La Liga">La Liga</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup> Three weeks later, on 1 October, Messi surpassed his former teammate Carles Puyol to become the third highest appearance maker in the club's history, as he helped Barça defeat Las Palmas 3–0 by assisting <a href="/wiki/Sergio_Busquets" title="Sergio Busquets">Sergio Busquets</a>' opener and later adding two himself in his 594th official game for the club; the league game was played behind closed doors at the Camp Nou due to violence in <a href="/wiki/Catalonia" title="Catalonia">Catalonia</a> relating to an <a href="/wiki/2017_Catalan_independence_referendum" title="2017 Catalan independence referendum">ongoing independence referendum</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 18 October, in his 122nd European club appearance, Messi scored his 97th UEFA Champions League goal, and his 100th in all UEFA club competitions, in a 3–1 home victory over <a href="/wiki/Olympiacos_F.C." title="Olympiacos F.C.">Olympiacos</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup> Messi became only the second player after Cristiano Ronaldo to reach this century milestone, but accomplished it in 21 fewer appearances than the Portuguese counterpart.<sup id="cite_ref-UEFA100_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UEFA100-238">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup> On 4 November, he made his 600th appearance for Barcelona in a 2–1 home win over Sevilla in La Liga.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup> Following the reception of his fourth <a href="/wiki/European_Golden_Shoe" title="European Golden Shoe">Golden Boot</a>, Messi signed a new deal with Barcelona on 25 November, keeping him with the club through the <a href="/wiki/2020%E2%80%9321_FC_Barcelona_season" title="2020–21 FC Barcelona season">2020–21 season</a>. His <a href="/wiki/Buyout_clause" title="Buyout clause">buyout clause</a> was set at €700&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup> On 7 January 2018, Messi made his 400th La Liga appearance with Barcelona in a 3–0 home win over Levante, marking the occasion with his 144th league assist and 365th league goal for the club, the latter of which saw him equal Gerd Müller's record for the most league goals scored for the same club in one of Europe's top five divisions.<sup id="cite_ref-Messi_breaks_Muller_goal_record_241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Messi_breaks_Muller_goal_record-241">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup> A week later, he broke the record, scoring his 366th La Liga goal from a free kick in a 4–2 away win against <a href="/wiki/Real_Sociedad" title="Real Sociedad">Real Sociedad</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Messi_breaks_Muller_goal_record_241-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Messi_breaks_Muller_goal_record-241">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 4 March, he scored his 600th senior career goal from a free kick in a 1–0 home win over Atlético Madrid, in La Liga.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup> On 14 March, Messi scored his 99th and 100th Champions League goals in a 3–0 home win over Chelsea, becoming only the second player after Cristiano Ronaldo to reach this landmark, in fewer appearances, at a younger age and having taken fewer shots than his Portuguese counterpart.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">&#91;238&#93;</a></sup> His opening goal, which came after only two minutes and eight seconds, was also the fastest of his career, as Barcelona advanced to the <a href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_UEFA_Champions_League_knockout_phase#Quarter-finals" title="2017–18 UEFA Champions League knockout phase">quarter-finals</a> of the <a href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_UEFA_Champions_League" title="2017–18 UEFA Champions League">competition</a> for the eleventh consecutive season.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">&#91;239&#93;</a></sup> On 7 April, he scored a hat-trick in a 3–1 win over <a href="/wiki/CD_Legan%C3%A9s" title="CD Leganés">Leganés</a> including his sixth goal scored from a free-kick for the season, matching the record set by former teammate Ronaldinho.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">&#91;240&#93;</a></sup> He once again finished the season as the top scorer in La Liga, with 34 goals, which also saw him win his fifth Golden Shoe award.<sup id="cite_ref-Messi5thGoldenShoe_246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Messi5thGoldenShoe-246">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup> On 21 April, Messi scored Barcelona's second goal – his 40th of the season – in a 5–0 win over Sevilla in the <a href="/wiki/2018_Copa_del_Rey_Final" title="2018 Copa del Rey Final">2018 Copa del Rey Final</a>, later also setting up Suárez's second goal; this was Barcelona's fourth consecutive title and their 30th overall.<sup id="cite_ref-2018CdR_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2018CdR-247">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup> On 29 April, Messi scored a hat-trick in a 4–2 away win over Deportivo de La Coruña, which saw Barcelona claim their 25th league title.<sup id="cite_ref-deportivo_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-deportivo-248">&#91;243&#93;</a></sup> On 9 May, Messi scored as Barcelona defeated <a href="/wiki/Villarreal_CF" title="Villarreal CF">Villarreal</a> 5–1 to set the <a href="/wiki/Football_records_in_Spain#Games_without_a_loss" class="mw-redirect" title="Football records in Spain">longest unbeaten streak</a> (43 games) in La Liga history.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">&#91;244&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="2018.E2.80.9319:_Barcelona_captain.2C_tenth_La_Liga_title.2C_and_a_record_sixth_Golden_Boot"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2018–19:_Barcelona_captain,_tenth_La_Liga_title,_and_a_record_sixth_Golden_Boot">2018–19: Barcelona captain, tenth La Liga title, and a record sixth Golden Boot</span></h4>
<p>With the departure of former captain Andrés Iniesta in May 2018, Messi was named the team's new captain for the following <a href="/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_FC_Barcelona_season" title="2018–19 FC Barcelona season">season</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup> On 12 August 2018, he lifted his first title as Barcelona's captain, the <a href="/wiki/2018_Supercopa_de_Espa%C3%B1a" title="2018 Supercopa de España">Supercopa de España</a>, following a 2–1 victory over Sevilla. On 19 August, Messi scored twice in helping Barcelona defeat Alavés 3–0 in their first <a href="/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_La_Liga" title="2018–19 La Liga">La Liga</a> match of the season, with his first goal, a free kick that he rolled under the jumping Alavés wall, making history in being Barcelona's 6000th goal in La Liga.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup> On 18 September, Messi scored a hat-trick in a 4–0 home win over <a href="/wiki/PSV_Eindhoven" title="PSV Eindhoven">PSV Eindhoven</a> in Barcelona's opening <a href="/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_UEFA_Champions_League_group_stage#Group_B" title="2018–19 UEFA Champions League group stage">Champions League</a> group stage match of the season, setting a new record for most hat-tricks in the competition, with eight.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup> On 20 October, Messi scored and assisted in a 4–2 home win over Sevilla, but was later forced off in the 26th minute after falling awkwardly and injuring his right arm; tests later confirmed that he had fractured his radial bone, ruling him out for approximately three weeks.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup> On 8 December, Messi scored two free kicks – his ninth and tenth goals from set pieces during the calendar year – in a 4–0 away win over <i>Derbi barceloní</i> rivals Espanyol in La Liga; this was the first time ever that he had managed such a feat in the league. His first goal was also his 10th league goal of the season, making him the first player ever to reach double figures in La Liga for 13 consecutive seasons.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">&#91;249&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lionel_Messi_vs_Valladolid_3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Lionel_Messi_vs_Valladolid_3.jpg/180px-Lionel_Messi_vs_Valladolid_3.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="243" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Lionel_Messi_vs_Valladolid_3.jpg/270px-Lionel_Messi_vs_Valladolid_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/37/Lionel_Messi_vs_Valladolid_3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="313" data-file-height="423" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Lionel_Messi_vs_Valladolid_3.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Messi taking a free-kick against <a href="/wiki/Real_Valladolid" title="Real Valladolid">Real Valladolid</a> in August 2018</div></div></div>
<p>On 13 January 2019, Messi scored his 400th La Liga goal in his 435th league appearance in a 3–0 home win over Eibar, becoming the first player ever to manage this tally in just one of Europe's top five leagues.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup> On 2 February, Messi scored twice in a 2–2 draw against Valencia, with his first goal coming from the penalty spot, his 50th La Liga penalty goal; as such, he became only the third player in La Liga history after Cristiano Ronaldo and <a href="/wiki/Hugo_S%C3%A1nchez" title="Hugo Sánchez">Hugo Sánchez</a> to score 50 penalties in the competition.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup> Later that month, the club admitted they had begun preparations for Messi's future retirement.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup> On 23 February, Messi scored the 50th hat-trick of his career and also provided an assist for Suárez, as he helped Barcelona come from behind to achieve a 4–2 away victory over Sevilla in La Liga; the goal was also his 650th career goal for club and country at senior level.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup> On 16 April, Messi scored twice in a 3–0 home victory over Manchester United in the second leg of the <a href="/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_UEFA_Champions_League_knockout_phase#Quarter-finals" title="2018–19 UEFA Champions League knockout phase">Champions League quarter-finals</a> to give Barcelona a 4–0 aggregate win, which saw Barcelona progress to the <a href="/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_UEFA_Champions_League_knockout_phase#Semi-finals" title="2018–19 UEFA Champions League knockout phase">semi-finals</a> of the competition for the first time since 2015; these were also his first goals in the Champions League quarter-finals since 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 27 April, Messi came off the bench and scored the only goal in a 1–0 home win over Levante, which allowed Barcelona to clinch the league title;<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup> this was his 450th La Liga appearance, and his first league title as Barcelona's captain.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup> On 1 May, Messi scored twice in a 3–0 home win over <a href="/wiki/Liverpool_F.C." title="Liverpool F.C.">Liverpool</a> in the first leg of the Champions League semi-finals; his second goal of the match, a 35-yard free kick, was the 600th senior club goal of his career, all of which had been scored with Barcelona.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup> In the return leg six days later at <a href="/wiki/Anfield" title="Anfield">Anfield</a>, Barcelona suffered a 4–0 away defeat, which saw Liverpool advance to the <a href="/wiki/2019_UEFA_Champions_League_Final" title="2019 UEFA Champions League Final">final</a> 4–3 on aggregate.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup> On 19 May, in Barcelona's final La Liga match of the season, Messi scored twice in a 2–2 away draw against Eibar (his 49th and 50th goals of the season in all competitions), which saw him capture his sixth Pichichi Trophy as the league's top scorer, with 36 goals in 34 appearances; with six titles, he equalled Zarra as the player with the most top-scorer awards in La Liga.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">&#91;261&#93;</a></sup> He also captured his sixth Golden Shoe award, and a record third consecutive award since the 2016–17 season.<sup id="cite_ref-Messi_wins_his_sixth_Golden_Shoe_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Messi_wins_his_sixth_Golden_Shoe-267">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup> On 25 May, Messi scored his final goal of the season in a 2–1 defeat to Valencia in the <a href="/wiki/2019_Copa_del_Rey_Final" title="2019 Copa del Rey Final">2019 Copa del Rey Final</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="2019.E2.80.9320:_A_record_sixth_Ballon_d.27Or"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2019–20:_A_record_sixth_Ballon_d'Or">2019–20: A record sixth Ballon d'Or</span></h4>
<p>On 5 August 2019, it was announced that Messi would miss Barcelona's <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">US</a> tour after sustaining a right <a href="/wiki/Calf_(leg)" title="Calf (leg)">calf</a> injury.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup> On 19 August, Messi's chipped goal from the edge of the box against Real Betis was nominated for the <a href="/wiki/The_Best_FIFA_Football_Awards_2019#FIFA_Puskás_Award" title="The Best FIFA Football Awards 2019">2019 FIFA Puskás Award</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup> Later that month, he suffered another setback following the return of his calf injury, which ruled him out of the opening game of the season;<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup> as a result, he was sidelined indefinitely, and was only expected to return to action with Barcelona after the September international break.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">&#91;267&#93;</a></sup> On 2 September, Messi was shortlisted as one of the three finalists for both the 2019 FIFA Puskás Award and the <a href="/wiki/The_Best_FIFA_Football_Awards_2019#The_Best_FIFA_Men&#39;s_Player" title="The Best FIFA Football Awards 2019">2019 Best FIFA Men's Player Award</a>, with Messi winning the latter on 23 September.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">&#91;268&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Messi_FIFA2019_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Messi_FIFA2019-274">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Messi made his first appearance of the <a href="/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_FC_Barcelona_season" title="2019–20 FC Barcelona season">season</a> on 17 September, and on 6 October he scored his first goal of the season with a free kick in a 4–0 home win over Sevilla; this was his 420th goal in La Liga, which saw him break Cristiano Ronaldo's record of 419 goals scored in Europe's top five leagues.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">&#91;270&#93;</a></sup> On 23 October, Messi scored his first <a href="/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_UEFA_Champions_League" title="2019–20 UEFA Champions League">Champions League</a> goal of the season in a 2–1 away win over <a href="/wiki/SK_Slavia_Prague" title="SK Slavia Prague">Slavia Prague</a>, becoming the first player to score in 15 consecutive Champions League seasons (excluding qualifying rounds).<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">&#91;271&#93;</a></sup> He also equalled Raúl and Cristiano Ronaldo's shared record of the most sides scored against in the competition (33).<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup> On 29 October, Messi scored and assisted twice in a 5–1 home win over <a href="/wiki/Real_Valladolid" title="Real Valladolid">Real Valladolid</a> in <a href="/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_La_Liga" title="2019–20 La Liga">La Liga</a>; his first goal – a set piece from 35 yards – was the 50th free-kick of his career.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">&#91;273&#93;</a></sup> His goals (608) also saw him overtake Cristiano Ronaldo's senior goal tally (606) at club level.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup> On 9 November, Messi scored three goals (including two free kicks) in a 4–1 home win against Celta Vigo. This was his 34th hat-trick in La Liga, equalling Cristiano Ronaldo's Spanish top-flight record.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup> On 27 November, in what was his 700th appearance for Barcelona, Messi scored one goal and assisted two more in a 3–1 home win over <a href="/wiki/Borussia_Dortmund" title="Borussia Dortmund">Borussia Dortmund</a> in the UEFA Champions League. Borussia Dortmund was the 34th team he had scored against in the competition, breaking the previous record of 33 held by Cristiano Ronaldo and Raúl.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup> On 2 December, Messi was awarded a record-breaking <a href="/wiki/2019_Ballon_d%27Or" title="2019 Ballon d&#39;Or">sixth Ballon d'Or</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_282-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-282">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup> On 8 December, Messi scored his record-breaking 35th hat-trick in La Liga with three goals in Barcelona's 5–2 home win over <a href="/wiki/RCD_Mallorca" title="RCD Mallorca">Mallorca</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">&#91;278&#93;</a></sup> 
</p><p>On 22 February 2020, Messi scored four goals in a 5–0 home win over Eibar in La Liga.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">&#91;279&#93;</a></sup> On 14 June, in a 4–0 away win against Mallorca, Messi assisted twice and scored another, becoming the first player ever in La Liga to score 20 goals or more in 12 consecutive seasons.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup> On 30 June, he scored a <a href="/wiki/Panenka_(penalty_kick)" title="Panenka (penalty kick)">panenka</a> in a 2–2 home draw against Atlético Madrid in La Liga, to reach his 700th goal in his senior career for Barcelona and Argentina.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup> On 11 July, Messi provided his 20th assist of the league season for <a href="/wiki/Arturo_Vidal" title="Arturo Vidal">Arturo Vidal</a> in a 1–0 away win over Real Valladolid, equalling Xavi's record of 20 assists in a single La Liga season from 2008 to 2009;<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">&#91;282&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Messi_matches_Henry_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Messi_matches_Henry-289">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup> with 22 goals, he also became only the second player ever, after <a href="/wiki/Thierry_Henry" title="Thierry Henry">Thierry Henry</a> in the <a href="/wiki/2002%E2%80%9303_FA_Premier_League" title="2002–03 FA Premier League">2002–03 FA Premier League</a> <a href="/wiki/2002%E2%80%9303_Arsenal_F.C._season" title="2002–03 Arsenal F.C. season">season with Arsenal</a> (24 goals and 20 assists), to record at least 20 goals and 20 assists in a single league season in one of Europe's top–five leagues.<sup id="cite_ref-Messi_matches_Henry_289-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Messi_matches_Henry-289">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup> Following his brace in a 5–0 away win against Alavés in the final match of the season on 20 May, Messi finished the season as both the top–scorer and top assist provider in La Liga, with 25 goals and 21 assists respectively, which saw him win his record seventh Pichichi trophy, overtaking Zarra; however, Barcelona missed out on the league title to Real Madrid.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">&#91;286&#93;</a></sup> On 9 August, in the <a href="/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_UEFA_Champions_League#Round_of_16" title="2019–20 UEFA Champions League">Champions League round of 16</a> second leg versus <a href="/wiki/S.S.C._Napoli" title="S.S.C. Napoli">Napoli</a> at the Camp Nou, Messi scored the second goal and earned a penalty which led to a third goal and led his side to a 3–1 home victory and qualified 4–2 on aggregate for the <a href="/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_UEFA_Champions_League" title="2019–20 UEFA Champions League">quarter-finals</a> against Bayern Munich.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">&#91;287&#93;</a></sup> On 15 August, Messi suffered his worst defeat as a player as <a href="/wiki/FC_Barcelona_2%E2%80%938_FC_Bayern_Munich" title="FC Barcelona 2–8 FC Bayern Munich">Bayern Munich beat Barcelona 8–2</a> in a one-off tie in <a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">Lisbon</a>, leading to another disappointing exit from the Champions League.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">&#91;288&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="August_2020:_Desire_to_leave_Barcelona">August 2020: Desire to leave Barcelona</span></h4>
<div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:33%; ;"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1012376600"/>
<div class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">“I wasn't happy and I wanted to leave. I have not been allowed this in any way and I will stay at the club so as not to get into a legal dispute. The management of the club led by <a href="/wiki/Josep_Maria_Bartomeu" title="Josep Maria Bartomeu">Bartomeu</a> is a disaster. My love for Barca will never change."</div>
<p><cite class="left-aligned" style="">– Messi on reversing his decision to leave Barcelona in an interview with <a href="/wiki/Goal_(website)" title="Goal (website)">Goal</a> on 4 September 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">&#91;289&#93;</a></sup></cite>
</p>
</div>
<p>Following growing dissatisfaction with the direction of Barcelona on and off the field,<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">&#91;290&#93;</a></sup> Barcelona announced that Messi sent the club "a document expressing his desire to leave" on 25 August 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">&#91;291&#93;</a></sup> The announcement garnered a significant media response, including from current and former teammates (who supported Messi's statement) and Catalan president <a href="/wiki/Quim_Torra" title="Quim Torra">Quim Torra</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">&#91;292&#93;</a></sup> On August 26, Barcelona's sporting director Ramon Planes iterated the club's desire to "build a team around the most important player in the world"<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">&#91;293&#93;</a></sup> and affirmed Messi will only be able to leave should a buyer pay his €700 million buyout clause; a reported early termination option available in Messi's contract (which would have allowed him to leave the club for free) could only be exercised if he had communicated his decision to Barcelona by 31 May 2020, although the player's representatives argued the deadline should be set to 31 August, due to the <a href="/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_association_football" title="Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on association football">adjourned 2019–20 season</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup> On 30 August, <a href="/wiki/La_Liga" title="La Liga">La Liga</a> issued a statement stating Messi's contract and buyout clause are still active.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">&#91;295&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 4 September, Jorge Messi, Lionel's father and agent, released a statement in response to La Liga claiming the release clause "is not valid when the termination of the contract is by the player's unilateral decision from the end of the 2019–20 season", as stated in Messi's contract with Barcelona;<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">&#91;296&#93;</a></sup> moments later, La Liga issued a response reiterating their statement published on 30 August.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">&#91;297&#93;</a></sup> Later that evening, Messi announced in an interview with <a href="/wiki/Goal_(website)" title="Goal (website)">Goal</a> that he would continue at Barcelona for the final year of his contract.
